story.storykicker: May we suggest Taher Shah's song to take the battle to the next level?
story.storybody:
British special forces are using Bollywood music as a psychological warfare weapon to battle against terrorist organisation ISIS in Libya, according to reports. 

But how is Bollywood music a weapon?

Apparently, ISIS fighters consider Bollywood music as blasphemy against Islam. 

The suggestion came from a Pakistani-born British army intelligence officer, who told them that ISIS would consider 

Bollywood music 'apostasy', and take offense due to their ultra-conservative interpretation of Islam. 

The British special forces decided to terrorise the ISIS fighters using tunes from popular Indian films. 

Acting on the intelligence, the psychological operations unit in Libya 'intercepted the insurgent's communications and blasted them with Bollywood chart music', The Mirror reports.

British forces are training Libyan troops to drive out ISIS from the town of Sirte and a 185-km stretch of the Libyan coastline. Soldiers of both the countries dumped two cars with Bollywood music blaring out near Sirte.

 
Also read: Islamic State halts Iraqi army at gates of Fallujah, civilians in crossfire
 
 
In Iraq, ISIS fighters used a human shield of 20,000 children to stall Iraqi military's advance into Fallujah.

It has been two years since the terrorist organisation seized the city in central Iraq and more than 50,000 civilians continue to be stuck inside Fallujah.

Out of the 50,000 the UN has estimated that 20,000 are children and face a risk of forced recruitment.

If British special forces succeed in their attempt to terrorise the ISIS using Bollywood songs then to take the battle to another level they should consider using Pakistani singer Taher Shah's songs!
